articles.title: Trump says government will 'de-escalate' in Minnesota following Pretti shooting
articles.snippet: The killing of Alex Pretti over the weekend led Minnesota officials and locals to renew calls for Trump to end his immigration operation there.

articles.title: Minnesota congresswoman Ilhan Omar attacked with unknown liquid at event
articles.snippet: Omar was uninjured and continued to speak at the event following the incident.

articles.title: Zelensky condemns Russian drone strike that killed five on passenger train
articles.snippet: Drones targeted a packed train in north-eastern Ukraine, officials say.

articles.title: South Korea's ex-first lady jailed for 20 months for bribery
articles.snippet: Kim Keon Hee was also ordered to return a Graff diamond necklace and pay back 12.85m won in cash.

articles.title: 'We all know someone who was killed' -  Iran protesters tell BBC of brutal crackdown
articles.snippet: Young Iranians able tell the BBC how they saw friends and other people die as security forces crushed protests earlier this month.

articles.title: Rwanda seeks £100m from UK over axed asylum deal
articles.snippet: The African nation argues it is owed payments but the Home Office says it will fight the case.

articles.title: Malaysia football officials quit over foreign-born players scandal
articles.snippet: Fifa had accused Malaysia's football association of doctoring citizenship documents.

articles.title: Former French senator found guilty of drugging MP
articles.snippet: Joel Guerriau received a four-year prison sentence, 18 months of which are to be served behind bars.

articles.title: Mexico president asks South Korea for more BTS concerts
articles.snippet: About a million fans were vying for 150,000 concert tickets, which sold out in less than 40 minutes.

articles.title: Republicans wrestle with immigration message after Minneapolis backlash
articles.snippet: Some lawmakers are questioning the crackdown as public anger grows over two citizens killed by federal agents.

articles.title: EU's Kallas urges 'more European' NATO amid Trump rupture
articles.snippet: US President Donald Trump has made it clear he doesn't want to support Europe like previous administrations. Europe is now grappling with how best to maintain its own defenses.

articles.title: How Germany's skilled worker shortage exposes migration hurdles
articles.snippet: Germany is facing a massive shortage of skilled workers, from nurses to IT specialists. The country needs hundreds of thousands of professionals, but bureaucracy and political hurdles are slowing recruitment abroad.

articles.title: What 'banana republic' means — and why its history matters
articles.snippet: From plantations to political rhetoric, the term's evolution shows how a violent past can fade into metaphor, sometimes obscuring its true history.

articles.title: India: Deputy state leader among 5 killed in plane crash
articles.snippet: Ajit Pawar, the deputy chief minister of Maharashtra, the country's wealthiest state, was on board a private plane that crashed in western India. There were no survivors from the crash.

articles.title: Germany updates: Bundestag marks Holocaust Remembrance Day
articles.snippet: Germany's parliament is set to mark Holocaust Remembrance Day in the presence of a survivor. Meanwhile, five people were injured after shots were fired during a police car chase on Tuesday night. DW has more.

articles.title: Iraq faces return of ex-PM linked to 'Islamic State' rise
articles.snippet: Ex-prime minister Nouri al-Maliki is often seen as responsible for sectarian tensions and military mismanagement that made the "Islamic State" possible in Iraq. He's just been nominated as Iraq's next prime minister.

articles.title: South Korea: Former First Lady sentenced to jail for bribery
articles.snippet: A South Korean court has sentenced Kim Keon Hee, the wife of disgraced ex-president Yoon Suk Yeol, to 20 months in prison for corruption.

articles.title: Rwanda sues UK over contentious migrant deal
articles.snippet: Rwanda accuses the UK of "intransigence" and says London owes it millions of pounds over a controversial migration agreement.

articles.title: Zelenskyy condemns 'terrorism' after Russia hits train in Ukraine
articles.snippet: A drone struck a train carriage carrying nearly 200 passengers in Ukraine, in an attack authorities blamed on Russia.

articles.title: TikTok settles amid looming social media addiction trial
articles.snippet: The social video platform is among the companies facing accusations that their platforms deliberately addict and harm children.

articles.title: Hundreds feared dead in attempt to cross Mediterranean during cyclone
articles.snippet:
Fifty killed in one incident as Italian authorities estimate 380 people may have drowned last week
Up to 380 people may have drowned attempting to cross the Mediterranean last week as Cyclone Harry battered southern Italy and Malta, the Italian coastguard has said, as a shipwreck with the loss of 50 lives was confirmed by Maltese authorities.
Just one person, who was hospitalised in Malta, survived the shipwreck, which happened on Friday.
 Continue reading...

articles.title: Crocodile warnings as floods devastate southern Africa
articles.snippet:
More than 100 people killed and hundreds of thousands displaced in South Africa, Mozambique and Zimbabwe
Devastating floods have killed more than 100 people in southern Africa since the beginning of the year and displaced hundreds of thousands, as authorities and aid workers warn of hunger, cholera and attacks by crocodiles that have spread with the waters.
More than 70 people have died in Zimbabwe and 30 in South Africa, where hundreds of people were evacuated from Kruger national park earlier this month after a deluge of rain.
 Continue reading...

articles.title: ‘It’s the sovereignty of the country’: Guinea-Bissau says US vaccine study suspended
articles.snippet:
Despite US pushback, officials in west Africa say controversial hepatitis B study on pause amid ethics concerns
US health officials insisted it was still on. African health leaders said it was cancelled. At the heart of the controversy is the west African nation of Guinea-Bissau – one of the poorest countries in the world and the proposed site of a hotly debated US-funded study on vaccines.
The study on hepatitis B vaccination, to be led by Danish researchers, became a flashpoint after major changes to the US vaccination schedule and prompted questions about how research is conducted ethically in other countries.
 Continue reading...

articles.title: ActionAid to rethink child sponsorship as part of plan to ‘decolonise’ its work
articles.snippet:
Development charity’s new co-chief executives signal shift from controversial sponsor a child scheme launched in 1972 to long-term grassroots funding
Child sponsorship schemes that allow donors to handpick children to support in poor countries can carry racialised, paternalistic undertones and need to be transformed, the newly appointed co-chief executives of ActionAid UK said as they set out to “decolonise” the organisation’s work.
ActionAid began in 1972 by finding sponsors for schoolchildren in India and Kenya, but Taahra Ghazi and Hannah Bond have launched their co-leadership this month with the goal of shifting narratives around aid from sympathy towards solidarity and partnership with global movements.
 Continue reading...

articles.title: Head of US Africa bureau urges staff to highlight US ‘generosity’ despite aid cuts
articles.snippet:
Email sent to diplomats by state department office’s new boss is labelled ‘racist’ after dismissing Africa as a priority
US diplomats have been encouraged to “unabashedly and aggressively” remind African governments about the “generosity” of the American people, according to a leaked email sent to staff in the US state department’s Bureau of African Affairs this January and obtained by the Guardian.
“It’s not gauche to remind these countries of the American people’s generosity in containing HIV/Aids or alleviating famine,” says the email.
 Continue reading...

articles.title: Can Venezuela’s Delcy Rodríguez become a Latin American Deng Xiaoping?
articles.snippet:
Maduro’s Sorbonne-educated successor is talking up an era of ‘reform and opening up’ modelled on China’s post-Mao boom
After years of political and social upheaval, hunger and despair, the Great Helmsman departs and is replaced by a francophile economic reformer who catapults a traumatised country into a new era of prosperity and growth.
That is what happened in China half a century ago when the croissant-loving communist Deng Xiaoping became paramount leader after Chairman Mao Zedong’s 1976 death and set in motion one of history’s biggest economic booms.
 Continue reading...

articles.title: Mexico’s president says cancellation of oil shipment to Cuba is ‘sovereign’ decision
articles.snippet:
Claudia Sheinbaum denied move was response to pressure from the US, after Trump said ‘zero’ oil would go to Cuba
Mexico has cancelled a shipment of oil to Cuba, the country’s president, Claudia Sheinbaum, appeared to confirm on Tuesday, but she insisted the decision was “sovereign” and not a response to pressure from the US.
Fuel shortages are causing increasingly severe blackouts in Cuba, and Mexico has been the island’s biggest oil supplier since the US blocked shipments from Venezuela last month.
 Continue reading...

articles.title: Five-year-old deported to Honduras despite being US citizen is latest child victim of Trump crackdown
articles.snippet:
Mother whose visa application was pending says she will send girl back to US soon accompanied by another relative
Five-year-old Génesis Ester Gutiérrez Castellanos misses her cousins, classmates and kindergarten teachers in Austin, Texas. Despite being a US citizen, she was deported on 11 January alongside her mother, Karen Guadalupe Gutiérrez Castellanos, to Honduras, a country Génesis had never known.
Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents were acting on an administrative deportation order against Gutiérrez, 26, issued in 2019, before Génesis was born.
 Continue reading...

articles.title: Canadian ex-Olympian pleads not guilty to 17 felonies including drug trafficking
articles.snippet:
Authorities allege Ryan Wedding, 44, ‘turned to a life of crime’ after his snowboarding career ended
Ryan Wedding, the Canadian former Olympic snowboarder accused of cocaine distribution and orchestrating several murders, appeared on Monday in a southern California courtroom for arraignment.
The 44-year-old has been charged with drug trafficking, conspiracy to murder, witness tampering and money laundering, among other charges. Authorities allege that after his snowboarding career, Wedding “turned to a life of crime” as a narcotics trafficker and led an organization that moved cocaine from South America to the US and Canada.
 Continue reading...

articles.title: Guyanese businessman facing US extradition elected opposition leader
articles.snippet:
Azruddin Mohamed’s election comes six months after he formed political party that became country’s second largest
A Guyanese businessman facing extradition to the US on gold-smuggling and money-laundering charges has been elected as the country’s opposition leader, six months after he formed a political party that quickly became the second largest in the South American country.
Azruddin Mohamed, 38, was confirmed as Guyana’s opposition leader after 16 lawmakers from the We Invest in Nationhood party (Win) and another from a single-seat outfit voted in his favor. The tally made Win the second-largest party in parliament, securing Mohamed’s election even as a magistrate’s court hears state arguments for his extradition to the US.
 Continue reading...

articles.title: Philip Glass pulls new symphony from Kennedy Center in protest of Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Philip Glass has announced he is withdrawing the world premiere of his Lincoln symphony from Kennedy Center, saying that the values of Trump-led Kennedy Center are “in direct conflict” with symphony’s message.

articles.title: Watch the video: EU-India trade deal — what's inside?
articles.snippet: The EU signed a historic trade deal with India on Tuesday. Why? Because with Trump in the White House and the European relations with Beijing being complicated, Brussels needs new friends. And it needs them fast.

articles.title: Bitter cold grips eastern US as ice forms on rivers

articles.title: Beyond boubou and wax prints: Africa Fashion Tour changes perceptions of African creativity
articles.snippet: African women’s wardrobes are diverse. Quite mixed, African fashion is sometimes traditional, sometimes Western, and sometimes a combination. It is unclassifiable when using a Western frame of reference.

articles.title: Combating the climate crisis to promote peace in Mali
articles.snippet: Between 1970 and 2020, the country experienced at least 40 major climate shocks, with drought affecting around 400,000 people each year and reducing crop revenues by US$9.5 million annually, according to the World Bank.

articles.title: What does ‘partnership’ really mean for Africa and the European Union?
articles.snippet: While the African Union designated 2025 as the Year of Reparations, European engagement throughout the year largely remained confined to acknowledgements rather than commitments.

articles.title: Is the Chinese presence in Congo Brazzaville a threat to ‘first occupants’ or a relief to them?
articles.snippet: The decline of the forest, following extractive work, deforestation, tree cutting, agricultural expansion, illegal logging, and other works in the forest areas of Congo, is shrinking the habitat of Indigenous peoples.

articles.title: Cameroonians shift toward clean cooking solutions with eco-charcoal
articles.snippet: Eco-charcoal, a product made using methods and materials that minimize environmental harm, is gradually replacing traditional charcoal in some households in Cameroon’s capital, Yaounde.

articles.title: Senegal: Where women’s bodies belong to everyone but themselves
articles.snippet: In Senegal, women who are victims of rape can be condemned for trying to take control of their lives. Society decides what is best for women.

articles.title: Kenyan filmmaker Emily Nderitu shows the world how to talk about climate change in Africa
articles.snippet: "We’re not short of knowledge or courage in Africa. We’re short of recognition. Storytelling can fix that. It can close the gap between visibility and value."

articles.title: Sixteen days of activism amid the rise of digital harm across Africa
articles.snippet: Across Africa, Reporters Without Borders has documented sustained online harassment and surveillance targeting women journalists in West Africa, noting that digital abuse has become an emerging barrier to press freedom.

articles.title: China’s green power in Angola: When clean energy comes with heavy debt
articles.snippet: In recent years, Chinese international investment schemes have increasingly emphasized “green development” and a “Green Belt and Road,” with hydropower positioned as a climate-friendly alternative to fossil fuels.

articles.title: US to send ICE agents to Winter Olympics, prompting Italian anger
articles.snippet: The US federal agency says it will not play an immigration role at February's event in Milan-Cortina.

articles.title: India and EU announce 'mother of all trade deals'
articles.snippet: The long-awaited deal comes as both Delhi and Brussels contend with economic and geopolitical pressure from the US.

articles.title: Spain plans to give half a million undocumented migrants legal status
articles.snippet: The process will be available to foreign nationals without a criminal record who can prove they lived in Spain for five months prior to 31 December 2025.

articles.title: Sweden aims to lower age of criminal responsibility to 13 as gangs recruit children
articles.snippet: Critics say the proposal could see even younger children becoming offenders as well as breaching children's rights.

articles.title: 'Major step': French MPs vote in favour of bill to ban social media for under-15s
articles.snippet: If the bill passes the upper house it could take effect by the start of France's new school year in September.

articles.snippet: No breakthrough is reported at the first three-way talks but reports suggest they will resume next month.

articles.snippet: The incident happened in Salamanca, a city particularly subject to gang-related violence.

articles.snippet: Ramón Guanipa's father was accused of treason for challenging the disputed 2024 presidential election result.

articles.title: The continued mysteries surrounding the intelligence operation to seize Maduro
articles.snippet: From intelligence sources to intricate mission plans, some details are becoming clearer - but many questions remain unanswered.

articles.title: US involvement in Venezuela could last years, Trump says
articles.snippet: The US president says only time would tell how long his administration will be involved in the running of the country.

articles.title: Venezuela inflates release figures as political prisoners remain in limbo
articles.snippet: As Venezuelan authorities claim a mass release of political prisoners, families wait outside detention centers without answers, or guarantees. Behind the government’s discourse of reconciliation, uncertainty and fear persist.

articles.title: The peacemakers: Meet Venezuelans who are fighting to free political detainees
articles.snippet: In Venezuela, relatives and human-rights NGOs have stepped up calls for the immediate release of more than 800 victims of politically-motivated persecution of the government formerly led by Nicolás Maduro.

articles.title: Venezuela after Maduro: Leadership of the South American nation seems uncertain
articles.snippet: Since the airstrikes, there has been a huge sense of uncertainty, with long queues in local supermarkets and gas stations, and Caracas residents worried about basic necessities like groceries.

articles.title: A new, terrifying sound: A Venezuelan account of the the attack on Caracas
articles.snippet: “I thought Venezuelans had already heard every sound the country’s violence had to offer. But this was something new — terrifying in its unfamiliarity.”

articles.title: ‘Clean up your culture’: a TV host’s comment makes Indigenous Brazilians speak up
articles.snippet: “Access to technology should be a guaranteed right to the all Brazilian citizens. To have a cell phone doesn't make (anyone) less Indigenous.”

articles.title: Dominican Republic wastes renewable energy while fossil fuel thermoelectric plants operate above legal limits
articles.snippet: Non-compliance with Technical Minimum Power, causing a greater injection of fossil-fuel-generated energy into the grid, violates Dominican legislation and hinders climate commitments, especially when renewable energy companies’ production remains restricted.

articles.title: Social networks fuel youth mobilization on Argentina’s streets
articles.snippet: Unlike movements in earlier decades, Argentina’s latest youth-led protests are increasingly organized digitally through platforms like TikTok, Instagram, and Whatsapp, rather than through unions or political parties.

articles.title: Life at the U.S.–Mexico border under the Trump administration
articles.snippet: The Trump administration has reintroduced some of its most contentious border measures, leading to renewed targeting, detention, and deportation of migrant communities, leaving thousands seeking safety in increasingly perilous conditions.

articles.title: At COP30, civil society stepped into real, not symbolic, leadership
articles.snippet: After several conferences shaped by restrictions and tensions between governments and social movements, this COP had active voices in the discussions from grassroots organizations, Indigenous peoples, and traditional communities.

articles.title: ‘Femicide does not start on the day of the crime’: A Brazilian researcher’s view on gender violence in her country
articles.snippet: [Femicide] starts when psychological violence is minimized, when a partner’s control is normalized as jealousy, when jokes or demeaning comments about women are seen as humor.

articles.title: Maharashtra deputy chief minister dies in plane crash
